oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daniel, Susan Garretson
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Rutherford County Historical Society Publication No. 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 5? SOME ACTUAL WILLS OF RUTHERFORD COUNTY, TENNESSEE 1802 - 1882 by Susan Garretson Daniel In the Autumn of 1977 while abstracting some of the county records, I discovered that there were filed envelopes of original wills located in the County Court Clerk's office. These envelopes are the inexpensive sort one would find at a dime store. In the first place the envelopes have a high acid content, which over the years can do terrific damage to anything con-tained in them. In the second place, the envelopes' limiting size (approxi-mately ^4-" X 8") had forced the wills, written on large legal-sized documents, to be folded many times which only increased the destruction process. Although, it was obvious from the record books (where wills were recorded until 1882) that not all the actual wills had survived, over a thousand had made the hard journey through the events of history in Rutherford County from the earliest will dated in 1802 to 1882. Some were literally turning to dust as the acids of the envelopes as well as the acids of 19th century inks did their work. I felt something had to be done before the county lost one of its precious legacies from the past these actual hand-written documents rich with the history of the people and places of Rutherford County. I discussed the problem with fellow member. Dr. Jim Huhta. We decided the people at the State Library and Archives in Nashville had the best facilities and expertise for preservation anywhere nearby. So I plucked up my courage and asked for an appointment with the State Archivist, Mrs. Cleo Hughes. I explained why I was there and she immediately applauded my idea that the wills were definitely worth the effort of preservation. She invited her assistant, Mr. Max Mendelsohn and the head of the microfilming and preservation section, Mr. Gene Hollars, to join our conversation. During the discussion we decided on a plan that would preserve the wills and at the same time place their images on microfilm for permanent accessibility by the public. I next approached the Rutherford County Historical Society whose members unanimously approved the project. The Society would pay the cost of purchasing acid-free folders for housing each will; and, at the same time, approved protecting the most deteriorated wills by laminating them. The Society allocated spending between $300-500. The State Archives would in 59 turn, microfilm the wills free of charge if they were allowed to keep the camera negative. One copy of the microfilm woiild be donated by State Archives and the Society could buy more copies of the microfilm for $12.00 a reel. Originally, it had been thought that the wills would fit on one reel of micro-film; but, as we got into the project, we learned that Rutherford Countians were "long-winded". We now have four reels of microfilmed wills dating from 1802-1882. State Archives personnel, trained in preservation techniques, would determine which wills needed lamination protection to preserve them from their rapidly deteriorating and destructive process. The only charge to the Society for the lamination would be the cost of the materials used. State Archives personnel would clean the wills, which included the process of deacidification, dry, press and laminate them in their well-equipped laboratory. The next step was to arrange the wills alphabetically for the microfilming, not a small task. Originally it had been hoped that Middle Tennessee State University students from the classes of Dr. Huhta and Dr. Ernest Hooper would be able to help in this process. However, the project did not get underway until April, 1978, which was near the end of the school year. I had student help for two or three times but after that the project fell into the laps of myself and Dr. Hooper. (We were also assisted occasionally by Mrs. Hooper). On the upper right comer of each will we printed in soft lead pencil the testator's name, the date of the will (DOW) and the date filed in court (f) or recorded (R) if shown. I decided that the wills seemed to fall into four groups. I had thought that we could group the wills according to the dates they had been filed or "proved" in court, but many of them only showed the date they had been written and in one instance no dates at all. It would have taken a great deal of research in the records books to determine the file dates and time seemed important considering their deteriorating condition. Therefore, I decided to make the four groups according to when the will had been written. Some researchers may find this inconvenient; but, since all four groups are alphabetized according to surnames, I do not believe too much search time will be wasted. The four groups are: I8O2-I836, 1837-1852, I853-I867, and 1868-1882. I forsee later an index to all named individuals within each will. Through all this the County Court Clerk, Mr. Ed Elam, has given us every consideration in allowing us access to the wills. Mr. Elam and I 60 decided to Xerox all the vd.lls one last time to insure against accidental loss (although great precautions were taken) during the time they were to be away from our County. Therefore, at the County Court Clerk's office researchers will find not only the microfilm reels but also a xeroxed copy of each will. When the actual wills return to the Courthouse (sometime in November 1978) great care will be taken to allow as little handling as possible. If a researcher desires to see the actual will, the county court cleric will make a decision as to the merit of the use on an individual basis. Arising out of the Society's efforts to preserve these old wills was a plaJi set forth to the County Public Works Committee to form an Archives for oiar county. With the promised assistance of the State Archives and the enthusiastic approval of our Rutherford County Commissioners, we will, in the not too distant future, have our own County Archives. We will be able to draw all our old county records into one place for preservation and safe-keeping and by having our records more accessible, at the same time foster pride in our local history and encourage writings on local events and characters. I feel that our country records, these wills are only an example, are exceptional and, despite the waste and destruction of time, have survived till now. They deserve to survive to the generations following us. 61 INDEX TO SOME ACTUAL WILLS OF RUTHERFORD COUNTY. TN 1802-1882 By Susan G.
